Description: Limestone figure of a human-headed bird or cat (sphinx?). The figure is shown in a highly schematic way. The front legs crudely indicated, they are strictly parallel, straight and in a closed position. There is no indication of a tail. Whitish limestone, surface brown and shiny (from handling?), details of hair picked; stone seems fairly heavy and solid. The surface is very smooth.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Relatively common at Naukratis (British Museum GR 1886,0401.1519, GR 1886,0401.1518 and possibly GR 2011,5011.7; Boston MFA 86.394, Oxford, Ashmolean Museum A N1896-1908-G.72, AN1886.459, AN1886.458; Brussels Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire A.1852; Heidelberg Archäologisches Institut der Universität ST55). Petrie dated these, with other limestone figures, between the 6th and 4th centuries BC (Petrie 1886, 40, pl.19.1&3), though one was found in a Ptolemaic level (ibid.). Hogarth found one in a ‘5th century BC’ well deposit (Hogarth 1905, 122; Hogarth Diary 24-25/04/1903, well 2 bottom). These are identical style to the ‘concubine’ and drummer figures of the Saite period, also found in the mid 6th century BC levels of the Scarab Factory (Petrie 1886, 40, Level 335). Unprovenanced Late Period parallel (Petrie Museum UC59370). Some of the highly varied deviations from this form, such as lying sphinxes, may be later in date (British Museum 1886,0401.1396 and 1886,0401.1485), as they have Late Period or Ptolemaic parallels from Memphis (Anthes 1959; 1965, see also in terracotta Ashton 2003a, 77, Petrie Museum, UC 48012-6; Nicholson & Thomas 2013, 73, P-390) and Saqqâra (Quibbel 1907, pl.30.6a-c; see also in terracotta Jeffreys et. al. 1988, fig. 64, nos.77/308 and 77/u 209) and unprovenanced (Petrie Museum UC60105, see also in terracotta Török 1995, no. 126; 98-9, pl.65, no. 129). Anthes 1959. Mit Rahineh, 1955. Philadelphia, University Museum, University of Pennsylvania. Anthes 1965. Mit Rahineh, 1956. Philadelphia, University Museum, University of Pennsylvania. Ashton, S. A. 2003, Petrie’s Ptolemaic and Roman Memphis, London. Gubel, E. 1998. E pluribus unum: Nubian, Libyan and Phoenician “Bastet”-sphinxes. In W. Clarysse, A. Schoolrs, H. Willems (eds), Egyptian religion: the last thousand years; studies dedicated to the memory of Jan Quaegebeur. Vol 1 (OLA 84). Leuven : Peeters 629 -645. Jeffreys, D. G., Smith, H. S., Price, M., & Giddy, L. L, 1988. The Anubieion at Saqqâra. Egypt Exploration Society Excavation memoirs 54, London. Martin, G. T. 1981. The sacred animal necropolis at North Saqqâra: the southern dependencies of the main temple complex. Egypt Exploration Society Excavation Memoirs 50, London. Quibell, 1907. Excavations at Saqqara 1905-1906. Le Caire: Imprimerie de l'Institut français d'archéologie orientale. Török, L. 1995, Hellenistic and Roman Terracottas from Egypt, Roma. Thomas, R. I. & Nicholson, P. T. 2013. Figurines in Nicholson, P. T. (ed.) Working in Memphis: The production of faience at Roman period Kom Helul. London: Egypt Exploration Society: 41-74.

According to ledger and EEF list in Boston, this piece was apparently registered under two numbers, P.4546 (=86.394) and S.1323 (=86.176); the two ledger numbers are written on the piece in addition to the inventory number 86.394. The EEF list does not include a stone human-headed bird but only a terracotta one (P.4546).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (CE.149) (Phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4546 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
